{ "step_by_step_thinking": "Japanese encephalitis vaccine is not typically given to infants less than 6 months, so option A is true. Two primary doses are indeed given to children in the one to three year age group, making option B also true. In endemic areas, vaccination is given to cover children between one to nine years age group, so option D is true. However, booster doses are not given after 1 year and repeated every 3 years. Instead, a single booster dose is recommended 12 to 24 months after the primary series if ongoing exposure or re-exposure is expected.", "answer_choice": "C" }
